caption.p: Influenza A viral proteins and their functions.

tr.td: Viral polymerase proteins essential for viral RNA synthesis ( Shaw et al., 2008)

Recognizes and binds to host sialic acid receptor ( Muramoto et al., 2013) Mediates fusion of viral and endosomal membrane ( Muramoto et al., 2013) Necessary to prevent premature fusion of virus to endosome thus facilitating timely escape of viral genome into cytoplasm ( Ning et al., 2005)

Encapsidates viral genome ( Fukuyama and Kawaoka, 2011) Interacts with viral polymerase proteins ( Fukuyama and Kawaoka, 2011; Liedmann et al., 2014) Interacts with cellular components such as actin, import, and export machinery, etc. ( Fukuyama and Kawaoka, 2011)

Required for budding of new viral progenies from the surface of infected cells ( Zhang et al., 2015) Facilitates viral movement to infected cells by cleaving neuramic acid in respiratory tract mucins ( Zhang et al., 2015)
M1 – Provides support for virus ( Shaw et al., 2008) M2 – facilitates viral uncoating ( Shaw et al., 2008)

NS1 – Inhibits type I Interferon production, and type I IFN pre-mRNA processing ( De Clercq, 2006) NS2 – Mediates nuclear export of vRNPs ( Shen et al., 2015) NS2 – Regulates of viral RNA transcription ( Shen et al., 2015)
